creditline: The John R. Van Derlip Fund
description: Large tapestry sling. Also includes needlework. Red, brown, white, and gold. Long cord ending in small tassels on each end. Center and ends have diamond motif twining.
text: The sling’s pristine condition, large size, and elaborate construction point suggest a ceremonial function. The cradle of the sling lacks the slit commonly used in utilitarian slings to secure a projectile. Slings were important weapons in tinku battles. Tinku was a form of ritual engagement in which two opposing groups met in a violent battle—becoming one in the process. Such battles were intended to shed blood as an offering to deities and maintain balance between communities.
title: Ceremonial Sling
